none: Letter to Honorable George Glascock from W. R. Casith (Cavitt), circa January 1887
Letter to Honorable George Glascock from W. R. Casith (Cavitt), circa January 1887
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 24 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
1                                                                                   [Ca. 1887, Jan.?]

To the Hon Geo: Glascock, Chairman.
Sir;
        The undersigned would state in
reply to the complaint of Gen. Hardeman.
1st That after waiting for several weeks
for the committee to visit the college
and after having notified the members
of the Board to hold themselves in
readiness to meet the committee, last
week he instructed the Secretary to
convene the Board at Austin at 10 A.M,
to day in order to meet these charges;
that the members of the Board are now
in Austin and will meet the honorable
committee at any time and place they
may name.

IInd As a general answer to the charges
the undersigned feels authorized to
say for the Directory; 1st, That Genl
Hardeman was elected agent of the
Board for one year on — 1883: and on
— day 1884 he was re-elected for one
year; that since the expiration of that
time he had been holding over: that
on the 6th of Oct, 1886 he was given three
months leave of absence and an agent
appointed ad interim as shown by
the records, and that on Jan. — 1887
the Board determined by resolution
to go into the election of an agent
and that T. M. Scott was elected agent
of the board for the remainder of the

current college year, that while
Genl Hardeman was not actually re=
moved, the undersigned admits that the
effect of the action of the Board was to
remove him,
2nd The undersigned feels authorized
to state for the Board that in the
discharge of the trust committed to
them they were unanimously of the
opinion that the best interests of the
College required a change in the agent
of the Board and that the Board dis-
charge what they deemed their duty
although their personal feelings and
sympathies were with Gen: Hardeman
and against the performance of the un=
pleasant duty, 3rd He denies for the
Board that they were actuated by
any motive save what they considered
the interests of the college,
4th Should the Committee desire further
reasons than the above mentioned he
will promise that the board will be
with the Committee tomorrow and
will give the committee, if they
desire, the reasons which each had
for his vote in the matter and that
the same will satisfy the committee
of the honesty of purpose of the Board
and the justice of their action.
III, On the part of the Board he asks
the Committee to make the closest

current college year, that while

scrutiny into the vouchers and Books
of the College, into the expenditures
of the state appropriation and other
funds of the College, the records of
the Board and the Faculty, and every
detail in the management of the College,
For the truth of the above statements
he refers to the records of the Board,

Signed W R. Cavitt
President of the Board
of Directors of the A & M C
College of Texas

The image appears to be a formal record or minutes entry. The handwriting is cursive and fairly legible, thankfully. Top left corner, there's a "3". Then we start on the first line: "scrutiny into the vouchers and Books." It looks like an ampersand or a shorthand symbol for "and" between "vouchers" and "Books".
